title: How to Make & Use a Homemade Flea Trap

steps.title: Fill a large, shallow dish with water.
steps.content: Fill a large, shallow dish with water. Ideal containers for a dish soap flea trap include cookie sheets, rubber tote lids, plates, and pie plates. You want a container with a large surface area and short sides. [1] X Research source A shallow dish helps you catch as many fleas as possible because the short sides won’t act as a barrier for jumping fleas that might land in the trap.

steps.title: Add 1 to 2 tablespoons (15 to 30 mL) of dish soap.
steps.content: Add 1 to 2 tablespoons (15 to 30 mL) of dish soap. Squirt 1 to 2 tablespoons (15 to 30 mL) of liquid dish soap into the water. Swish the water around with a spoon or your finger to distribute the soap throughout the water. Fleas don’t drown in plain water because they aren't heavy enough to break the water’s surface tension. Adding liquid dish soap to the water reduces the surface tension. When the fleas jump into the trap, they sink and drown. [2] X Research source McCombe also recommends adding some Alka Seltzer to the water to make the trap more effective. [3] X Expert Source Scott McCombe Pest Control Specialist Expert Interview. 19 November 2019.

steps.title: Place the trap where fleas have been.
steps.content: Place the trap where fleas have been. A homemade flea trap doesn’t have the power to attract fleas, so it’s best to put it somewhere that fleas have already been in your house. Place a towel on the floor to catch spills, and lay the trap on top of the towel on the floor. Make multiple flea traps for different rooms if necessary. McCombe recommends placing the traps: [4] X Expert Source Scott McCombe Pest Control Specialist Expert Interview. 19 November 2019. On carpets and rugs. Near pet bedding. Near windows, doors, and food. Around pillows and furniture. Around pet bowls. Near drapes and curtains.

steps.title: Leave the trap overnight.
steps.content: Leave the trap overnight. Fleas become active a couple of hours before sunset and stay active all night long, so the best time to catch them is overnight. [5] X Research source Once you lay the trap, try to leave it undisturbed for the rest of the night. When possible, close the door to the room to keep pets and kids out.

steps.title: Empty and refill the trap each morning.
steps.content: Empty and refill the trap each morning. In the morning, check the trap for dead fleas. If you catch any, dump the soapy water and rinse the dish. Fill the dish with fresh water, add more dish soap, and lay the trap out again on the towel for the next night. [6] X Trustworthy Source EDIS Electronic database of the University of Florida Institute of Food and Agricultural Sciences's peer-reviewed articles Go to source Repeat each night until you stop catching fleas.

steps.title: Use a lamp to attract fleas.
steps.content: Use a lamp to attract fleas. McCombe recommends placing a directional or table lamp beside the trap. Before bed, turn on the lamp and position the bulb above the trap so the light shines into it. As McCombe explains, the fleas will be attracted to the light and warmth, and when they jump toward the light, they’ll land in the trap below. [7] X Expert Source Scott McCombe Pest Control Specialist Expert Interview. 19 November 2019. Use an incandescent or other heat-producing bulb for your trap to attract the most fleas possible. Make sure the lamp is sturdy and not at risk of being knocked over into the water. Use this attractant only in rooms where you can shut the door and keep people and pets out while the lamp is on.

steps.title: Use a yellow-green filter on a light.
steps.content: Use a yellow-green filter on a light. Fleas are, for some reason, twice as attracted to yellow-green light as they are to other colors of light. You can increase the efficacy of your lamp attractant by using a yellow-green bulb or by installing a yellow-green filter on a lamp with a regular bulb. [8] X Research source

steps.title: Place a candle in the center of the dish.
steps.content: Place a candle in the center of the dish. Use a tea light to create light and warmth to attract fleas to the trap. Place a tea light or votive candle at the center of the trap, and light the candle before bed. As the fleas try to get close to the source, they’ll fall into the trap and drown. [9] X Research source Place the trap away from walls, drapery, and other flammable objects. Always exercise great care and proper fire safety measures when burning candles. Close off the room to prevent people and pets from entering when the candle is lit.

steps.title: Place an indoor plant beside the trap.
steps.content: Place an indoor plant beside the trap. Fleas are attracted to carbon dioxide, which is part of the mechanism they use to find a host. Because plants release carbon dioxide at night, placing one beside the trap may help to attract more fleas. [10] X Research source Dormant flea pupae are particularly sensitive to carbon dioxide, so this may be a great way to catch young fleas before they have a chance to lay eggs. [11] X Research source

If a homemade flea trap doesn’t do the trick, consider purchasing a flea trap. Many products on the market are designed to attract, catch, and/or kill fleas. Based on our research, here are the most popular flea traps you can buy: Essentria is an essential oil-based product recommended by pest control specialist Chris Parker. [12] X Expert Source Chris Parker Founder, Parker Eco Pest Control Expert Interview. 18 February 2021. Terro Indoor Electric Flea Trap uses heat and light to lure fleas into a sticky glue trap. My Flea Trap uses green, intermittent light to attract and capture fleas. [13] X Research source Victor Flea Trap has an incandescent lightbulb and sticky floor trap. Aspektek Sticky Dome uses heat and light to attract fleas. [14] X Research source Redeo Flea Trap has adjustable light settings that can also attract moths. Phosooy Flea Trap has an adjustable light and glue board that attracts fleas, mites, moths, and mosquitoes.

steps.title: Bathe and comb your pets.
steps.content: Bathe and comb your pets. Pets are the most likely culprit for bringing fleas into your house, so keeping your pets clean and groomed can help stop the infestation at its source. [15] X Research source To treat your pet : Comb your pet’s fur with a flea comb , concentrating on the neck and tail. Swish the comb around in soapy water after each brush to kill fleas. After combing, soak your pet with a hose or in a tub. Lather your pet’s fur with a flea-controlling shampoo . Leave the shampoo on the fur for a few minutes. Rinse your pet down. Repeat regularly during the spring, summer, and fall.

steps.title: Vacuum regularly.
steps.content: Vacuum regularly. Adult fleas, eggs, larvae, and pupae can hide almost anywhere in your house, so you vacuum 3 to 4 times each week to stay on top of them. Use a strong vacuum that will suck fleas and eggs from the nooks and crannies in your house. [16] X Research source Use a brush or nozzle attachment for hard-to-reach areas. Vacuum floors, carpets, sideboards, furniture, around windows, and especially around areas where your pet spends the most time. McCombe advises discarding the contents of your vacuum in an outside trash can away from the house immediately. [17] X Expert Source Scott McCombe Pest Control Specialist Expert Interview. 19 November 2019.

steps.title: Wash bedding, drapery, clothes, and rugs.
steps.content: Wash bedding, drapery, clothes, and rugs. Fleas and eggs won’t survive a trip through the washing machine and dryer, so launder everything that can go into the washing machine and hand wash everything else. Use the hottest water and highest heat settings in the washer and dryer. [18] X Research source Items to wash include: Blankets Sheets Pillowcases Pillows Shoes Clothes Pet toys Pet bowls Towels

steps.title: Consider an insecticide.
steps.content: Consider an insecticide. Flea infestations can persist for months if you're not successful at removing all the fleas and their eggs . For stubborn infestations, use a pyrethrin-based pesticide with an insect growth regulator, such as Ultracide or Onslaught . Apply the insecticide inside and outside. Get everybody out of the house. Put on gloves, goggles, long sleeves, and a respirator to apply the insecticide. Use a dust or aerosol product and apply a light mist on floors, walls, furniture, and all other surfaces inside the house. Allow the dust or spray to settle before letting people back in. Vacuum after 48 hours. Outside, apply a layer of dust or spray to the garden, on bushes and shrubs, around tall grass, in wooded areas, and around windows and doors.
